title: Apoptosis
author: ayobami
description: Reviewing your knowledge about one of the ways a cell goes to die; apoptosis

questions.question: Caspases contain aspartate in their active site and cleave cysteine residues
In apoptosis, there is shrinkage of the cell due to the destruction of the cytoskeleton
BAX and BAK, the pro-apoptotic proteins work in the apoptotic extrinsic pathway to increase the permeability of the outer mitochondrial membrane
In the mitochondrial pathway, when cytochrome C is released, it immediately binds to and cleaves pro-caspase 9
In the mitochondrial pathway, when cytochrome C is released, it binds to Apoptosis activating factor-1 (APAF-1) to create an apoptosome
An apoptosome's function is to cleave procaspase-9 into caspase-9
Caspase 9, 3, and 10 are all initiation caspases
Caspase 6, 9, and 10 are all initiation caspases
Caspase 9, 8, and 10 are all initiation caspases
Apoptotic cell fragments express phosphatidylserine on their membranes that mediate their phagocytosis
Apoptosis in a particular site typically does not stimulate release of pro-inflammatory cytokines
Efferocytosis is the process of apoptotic cell component enzymatic digestion by caspases
The execution caspases, 3 and 8, help cleave cell components
In the extrinsic pathway, apoptosis is mediated by death receptors
A and C are substances that can bind to death receptors
A and B are substances that can bind to death receptors
C and E are death receptors
When a death domain is activated, there is cleavage of caspase-7 or 9
When a death domain is activated, there is cleavage of caspase-8 or 10
When apoptosis is followed by release of Interleukin-1 (IL-1), it is called pyroptosis
